stream_context.summary: Kaze’s birthday-stream focuses on Course 14. He demos a new crayon-drawing mechanic, prototypes a paper-spring platform, tweaks HUD filtering, and starts redesigning the snow biome where Luigi must recover a lost crayon. The session mixes live coding, level-design brainstorming, and philosophical riffs on difficulty and "placeness."

development_findings.summary: Implemented a pastel-crayon mechanic: the player can pick up Luigi’s crayon, draw on surfaces, and even color a star to collect it; a sound effect and automatic crayon-color change (to blue after collection) are on the to-do list.
development_findings.quote: Look at this cool thing I added off-stream. … If you color the star, you get a star. … When the crayon star is collected, make the crayon blue.

development_findings.summary: Experimented with bilinear filtering on HUD textures but reverted to crisp pixels to stay visually consistent with Mario 64’s original look.
development_findings.quote: We don't want to make arbitrary changes … When we make a change like that, we want it to be the same thing, but improved.

development_findings.summary: Declared existing Styrofoam-mountain set pieces "terrible" and decided to rebuild the area; the new plan turns it into a snow biome tied to the crayon-retrieval mission.
development_findings.quote: So the Styrofoam mountains, I have decided they're terrible and I want to redo them.

development_findings.summary: Struggled to visualize and model a folded paper spring; began building it bottom-up in Blender, aiming for an object Mario can bounce on with wobble animation.
development_findings.quote: I still can't figure out the geometry of this thing … I will just start 3D modeling it from the bottom.

development_findings.summary: Wrote physics code for the spring with squash-and-stretch and general-purpose sliding; iterated to reduce ‘jelly’ feel and make jumps predictable.
development_findings.quote: Those are great spring physics. They look realistic, but they're fudged enough to make this work.

development_findings.summary: Noted the red-coin section became too hard because the long-jump-to-ledge-grab is unforgiving; plans to add a higher platform and adjust slipperiness.
Brainstormed snow-biome assets: cotton snow, foam-toothpick snowmen enemies, falling glitter snowflakes via animated quads.
Needs a memorable entrance for the Bit Pipe; ideas include hidden door made visible by crayon strokes or a gift box that opens to reveal the pipe.
development_findings.quote: There could be a gift with a ribbon that you … unbox and the pipe is in it.

development_findings.summary: Star-collection screen is placeholder; wants polish without becoming "Cocomelon" flashy; considering post-star regain-control flow.
Re-evaluated level design philosophy: embrace seemingly random juxtapositions (à la Hazy Maze Cave) to boost a stage’s "placeness."
development_findings.quote: You kind of just need to be schizophrenic and make connections that don't actually exist in your levels to maximize on that concept.

context_findings.summary: It is Kaze’s birthday; Zeina made him chocolate milk and apparently bought cake.
Defines freedom in game design as the ability to attempt actions without penalty; views difficulty mainly as a filter that can block portions of the audience.
context_findings.quote: Difficulty means there's some group of players that cannot do it … freedom is the ability to do things without a penalty.

context_findings.summary: Believes Nintendo’s legal actions are calculated, not a reaction to individual ‘taunting’ tweets; jokes about marketing the game around potential takedowns.
context_findings.quote: Nintendo is not one meathead that's getting upset if you look at them the wrong way … they're a big company making calculated decisions.

context_findings.summary: Dismisses BlueSky as a viable social-media platform because of the network-effect hurdle.
context_findings.quote: Blue Sky doesn't really exist yet and it's never going to exist.

biobak.summary: Provided quick feedback on HUD clarity and dropped a birthday greeting.

zeina.summary: Brought Kaze chocolate milk and arranged birthday cake; no on-stream dev input this session.

key_stories.title: Birth of the Crayon Mechanic
key_stories.summary: Kaze showcases a brand-new system where players use Luigi’s crayon to draw directly in-game. Coloring a sketched star spawns a real Power Star, and future plans include changing crayon color and adding sound effects.
key_stories.challenge: Add an original, tactile mechanic that feels like child-friendly craft within Mario 64’s engine.
key_stories.process: Coded multi-controller input to let players ‘paint’; created pastel shader and linked star activation to colored pixels.
key_stories.outcome: Fully functional demo impresses chat; to-do list now includes audio feedback and dynamic crayon color swap.
key_stories.key_quote: Look at this cool thing I added … You can draw with a marker. Isn't this amazing?

key_stories.title: Paper Spring Prototype
key_stories.summary: Kaze attempts to model and code a spring made of folded paper. Understanding the real-world zig-zag fold proves unexpectedly tough, forcing a bottom-up 3D build and multiple physics tweaks.
key_stories.challenge: Create a believable paper spring that both looks right and delivers fun, predictable bounces.
key_stories.process: Studied real folds, mocked them in Blender, wrote squash-and-stretch physics, iterated on damping to avoid ‘jelly’ behavior.
key_stories.outcome: Version 1 works and feeds into a red-coin challenge, but difficulty balance and visuals still need refinement.
key_stories.key_quote: I still can't figure out the geometry of this thing … Those are great spring physics. They look realistic, but they're fudged enough to make this work.

key_stories.title: Snow Biome Reimagining
key_stories.summary: Unhappy with the current Styrofoam mountains, Kaze pivots to a cotton-snow setting where Luigi’s lost crayon quest becomes a mini-journey involving new enemies and obstacles.
key_stories.challenge: Existing area feels bland and ugly.
key_stories.process: Scrapped assets, brainstormed cotton snow, foam-toothpick snowmen, invisible platforms revealed by crayon, and gating via breakable boxes or buttons.
key_stories.outcome: No final assets yet, but a clearer creative direction and task list for the biome redesign.
key_stories.key_quote: We need this section to be fun. I want this to be a little bit of a journey, not the most easy thing ever.

key_stories.title: Placeness Revelation
key_stories.summary: A chat discussion about Hazy Maze Cave makes Kaze realize that seemingly random elements boost a level’s identity; vows to inject more ‘schizophrenic’ connections in future designs.
key_stories.challenge: Make levels feel memorable and lived-in rather than strictly logical.
key_stories.process: Analyzed why Hazy Maze Cave works (toxic maze, Dorrie, boulders). Concluded that embracing randomness enhances ambience.
key_stories.outcome: Design philosophy shift that will influence Course 14 and beyond.
key_stories.key_quote: You kind of just need to be schizophrenic and make connections that don't actually exist.

open_questions.topic: Technical implementation of the crayon-drawing system
open_questions.context: Kaze demonstrated drawing and star activation but didn’t explain input handling, texture memory limits, or performance impacts.
questions: How did you capture and store player drawing data on N64 hardware?
What optimizations keep the system performant?
How will this mechanic scale across multiple levels?

open_questions.context: He tweaked squash-stretch and damping but said visuals and predictability aren’t final.
questions: What mathematical model are you using for the spring?
Will players ever control spring strength (e.g., holding jump)?
How will Zeina’s animations integrate with the physics?
Any plans to reuse the spring code for other objects?

open_questions.context: Brainstormed cotton snow, foam-toothpick snowmen, glitter flakes, but no asset plan yet.
questions: What final material choice best conveys ‘craft’ snow on low-poly N64?
How will Biobak texture cotton or foam realistically?
Will Badub compose unique winter music for this area?

open_questions.context: Kaze wants more random juxtapositions like Hazy Maze Cave.
questions: Can he articulate design rules that balance randomness with coherence?
How does the team vet which ‘schizophrenic’ ideas stay?
Any examples already implemented in earlier courses?

open_questions.context: Location undecided; ideas include invisible platforms revealed by crayon or gift-box entrance.
questions: What final decision was made?
How does the reveal tie into player psychology and level flow?
Could Zeina animate gift-box opening for emotional punch?

open_questions.context: Kaze claims difficulty filters players and isn’t inherently fun.
questions: How will this stance shape late-game challenges?
Will there be optional ‘hard mode’ stars or self-imposed challenges encouraged by level design?

open_questions.context: Joked about prison marketing and tweeting Nintendo for rights.
